metadata.case_name: Balraj Madhok & Ors. v. State (Criminal Writ Petitions Nos. 2 to 10 of 1966)
metadata.case_number: Criminal Writ Petitions Nos. 2 to 10 of 1966

facts.text: Ugly incidents in Delhi on 7th November 1966.
Petitioners arrested between 7th and 13th November 1966 and detained in prison.
Petitioners not informed of reasons at arrest, not produced before any Magistrate.
Petitioners arrested under Section 107 read with Section 151 CrPC on apprehension of imminent danger of breach of peace.
Petitioners produced before Magistrates in Delhi who ordered release on bail with security; failure to furnish security led to judicial custody.
Example: Inspector Bhim Singh arrested Balraj Madhok, Amrit Lal, Mela Ram, Ram Saroop on 9th November 1966 under S.107/151 CrPC.

Magistrate N.K. Garg: On 9th November 1966, produced Balraj Madhok et al., apprised of arrest under 107/151, ordered bail with two sureties of Rs.10,000/- each or remand till 19th November; Mela Ram released, others not.

legal_issues.text: Whether arrest of petitioners under Section 151 CrPC was legal, given reason of apprehension of breach of peace.
Whether detention ordered by Magistrates was in accordance with law, particularly without order under Section 112 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Unlawfully detained; not informed of reasons at arrest; never produced before any Magistrate; no Magistrate informed them of offence or passed orders in their presence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 22 and 226 of Constitution, Section 491 CrPC

respondent_arguments.text: Arrested under Section 107 r/w 151 CrPC; produced before Magistrates who ordered bail, but petitioners failed to furnish security, hence remanded to judicial custody.
Police knew petitioners designed to commit cognizable offence.

court_reasoning.text: Arrest under S.151 requires knowledge of design to commit cognizable offence, not mere apprehension; S.107 not an offence; apprehension of breach of peace insufficient; enough time to seek Magistrate orders.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arrests not in accordance with law.

court_reasoning.text: Magistrates' affidavits regrettable, undermines impartiality; no order under S.112 (condition precedent) before remand; no competence to grant bail or remand without S.112; procedure in Chapter VIII CrPC not followed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detention not in accordance with law.

court_reasoning.text: Approved Allahabad HC in Sharon Kumar Gupta: Must prepare S.112 order first, read/explain it, only then remand under S.117(3) with recorded reasons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Magistrate powers vest only after S.112.

holdings.text: Arrest under S.151 CrPC illegal without knowledge of design to commit cognizable offence.
Detention illegal without preliminary order under S.112 CrPC in S.107 proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sharon Kumar Gupta v. Supdt., District Jail, Mathura
precedents_cited.relevance: Procedure under S.107 CrPC requires S.112 order before remand; quoted approvingly.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Arrest and detention procedures under preventive sections; mandatory S.112 order.

outcome.summary: Petitions allowed; petitioners directed to be set at liberty forthwith as arrests and detention illegal.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of habeas corpus issued; set at liberty.

key_quotes.text: The power given under this provision impinges on one of the important liberties of an individual. Hence it is necessary that exercise of that power, there should be strict compliance with the requirements, of the law.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes strict compliance for S.151 arrests.

key_quotes.text: An order under section 112 is the very basis of a proceeding under the chapter. Without such an order the Magistrate is incompetent to take further action.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: This conduct on their part is not likely to inspire confidence in the impartiality of the Magistrates.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Criticism of Magistrates filing affidavits for prosecution.
